'''Ubuntu''' ({{IPA2|uËËbuËntuË}} in English,<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.ubuntu.com/aboutus/faq/ | title = Frequently Asked Questions | publisher = Ubuntu | accessdate = 2008-05-13 }}</ref> {{IPA|[Ã¹ÉÃºntÃº]}} in [[Zulu language|Zulu]]) is a computer [[operating system]] based on [[Debian GNU/Linux]], a popular [[Linux distribution]]. Its name comes from the [[Zulu language|Zulu]] word "ubuntu", translated as humanity, describing the [[ubuntu philosophy]]: "I am who I am because of those around me," a positive aspect of [[community]]. Ubuntu's goals include providing an up-to-date, stable operating system for the average user, with a strong focus on [[usability]] and ease of installation. Ubuntu has been rated as the most popular Linux distribution for the desktop, claiming approximately 30% of desktop Linux installations in 2007.<ref name="Market Survey 2007">{{ cite web | title = 2007 Desktop Linux Market survey | url = http://www.desktoplinux.com/cgi-bin/survey/survey.cgi?view=archive&id=0813200712407 | date = [[2007-08-21]] | accessdate = 2008-08-19 }}</ref> Ubuntu is also used on some high profile servers, including those belonging to the [[Wikimedia Foundation]].<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20081009-wikipedia-adopts-ubuntu-for-its-server-infrastructure.html | title = Wikipedia adopts Ubuntu for its server infrastructure | publisher = Ars Technica | accessdate = 2009-01-09 }}</ref>
'''Ubuntu''' ({{IPA2|uËËbuËntuË}} in English,<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://www.ubuntu.com/aboutus/faq/ | title = Frequently Asked Questions | publisher = Ubuntu | accessdate = 2008-05-13 }}</ref> {{IPA|[Ã¹ÉÃºntÃº]}} in [[Zulu language|Zulu]]) is a computer [[operating system]] based on [[Debian GNU/Linux]], a popular [[Linux distribution]]. Its name comes from the [[Zulu language|Zulu]] word "ubuntu", translated as humanity, describing the [[ubuntu philosophy]]: "I am who I am because of those around me," a positive aspect of [[community]]. Ubuntu's goals include providing an up-to-date, stable operating system for the average user, with a strong focus on [[usability]] and ease of installation. Ubuntu has been rated as the most popular Linux distribution for the desktop, claiming approximately 30% of desktop Linux installations in 2007.<ref name="Market Survey 2007">{{ cite web | title = 2007 Desktop Linux Market survey | url = http://www.desktoplinux.com/cgi-bin/survey/survey.cgi?view=archive&id=0813200712407 | date = [[2007-08-21]] | accessdate = 2008-08-19 }}</ref> Ubuntu is also used on some high profile servers, including those belonging to the [[Wikimedia Foundation]].<ref>{{ cite web | url = http://arstechnica.com/news.ars/post/20081009-wikipedia-adopts-ubuntu-for-its-server-infrastructure.html | title = Wikipedia adopts Ubuntu for its server infrastructure | publisher = Ars Technica | accessdate = 2009-01-09 }}</ref>
â
Ubuntu is [[free and open source software]], meaning users are free to run, copy, distribute, study, change and improve the software under the terms of the [[GNU GPL license]]. Ubuntu is sponsored by the [[UK]] based company [[Canonical Ltd.]], owned by [[South Africa]]n entrepreneur [[Mark Shuttleworth]]. Instead of selling Ubuntu for profit, Canonical creates revenue by selling [[technical support]]. By keeping Ubuntu [[Free software | free]] and open source, Canonical is able to take advantage of the talents of outside developers in Ubuntu's constituent components without developing the entire operating system itself.
+
Ubuntu is [[free and open source software]], meaning users are free to run, copy, distribute, study, change and improve the software under the terms of the [[GNU GPL license]]. Ubuntu is sponsored by the [[United Kingdom|UK]] based company [[Canonical Ltd.]], owned by [[South Africa]]n entrepreneur [[Mark Shuttleworth]]. Instead of selling Ubuntu for profit, Canonical creates revenue by selling [[technical support]]. By keeping Ubuntu [[Free software | free]] and open source, Canonical is able to take advantage of the talents of outside developers in Ubuntu's constituent components without developing the entire operating system itself.
Canonical endorses and provides support for four additional Ubuntu-based distributions: [[Kubuntu]] and [[Xubuntu]], which use [[KDE]] and [[Xfce]], respectively, as a [[desktop environment]], replacing the default [[GNOME]] system used by Ubuntu; [[Edubuntu]], a subproject and add-on for Ubuntu, designed for school environments and home use;<ref>{{cite web |title=Edubuntu - Frequently asked questions |url=http://www.edubuntu.org/faq |accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> and [[Ubuntu JeOS]] (pronounced "Juice"), a stripped-down version of Ubuntu, optimized for [[virtual appliance]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.vmware.com/console/2007/07/get-juiced.html|title=Get Juiced!<!-- Bot generated title --> |accessdate=2008-06-02|first=Srinivas|last=Krishnamurti }}</ref>
Canonical endorses and provides support for four additional Ubuntu-based distributions: [[Kubuntu]] and [[Xubuntu]], which use [[KDE]] and [[Xfce]], respectively, as a [[desktop environment]], replacing the default [[GNOME]] system used by Ubuntu; [[Edubuntu]], a subproject and add-on for Ubuntu, designed for school environments and home use;<ref>{{cite web |title=Edubuntu - Frequently asked questions |url=http://www.edubuntu.org/faq |accessdate=2008-08-19}}</ref> and [[Ubuntu JeOS]] (pronounced "Juice"), a stripped-down version of Ubuntu, optimized for [[virtual appliance]]s.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.vmware.com/console/2007/07/get-juiced.html|title=Get Juiced!<!-- Bot generated title --> |accessdate=2008-06-02|first=Srinivas|last=Krishnamurti }}</ref>
